Dear Pamela Cornell-Allen:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact the area
manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:/(c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/27 or 6/28, Youth A and Youth B were in the recreation
space and should have been in visual sight of staff however staff
was in the kitchen making dinner. Staff was aware the youth were
in a different room and did not keep them within eyesight. Youth B
gave Youth A oral sex while they were in a corner hidden from the
camera’s view.
Investigation On 7/18/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the
Complainant. No additional concerns were noted.
On 7/18/2023 a meeting was held with Director at the facility.
The DHHS specialist was also present. Director was advised of
the allegations and notified that a special investigation was
initiated. Director reported two youth were present along with one
staff when the reported incident occurred. She stated Youth A
reported she and Youth B had participated in consensual oral sex.
She reported that the youth were in the recreation room when the
incident occurred. Director confirmed staff were utilizing the
cameras as a form of supervision because they were cooking
dinner. Director was asked about the agencies supervision policy,
and she reported policy states staff are to maintain “eyes on” or
within “an eye shot”. She reported incident reports were written
and submitted on 6/30/23 and 07/19/23. On 07/18/2023 a second
in-person meeting was held with Director. The supervision policy
was reviewed and discussed. The policy indicates the following:
“youth specialists are responsible for knowing the whereabouts of
youth and should monitor and supervise youth activities. The
primary function of residential staff is to ensure the safety of youth,
including enforcing rules and managing behaviors.” A safety plan
was also created with the DHHS specialist and Director. The plan
included that employees would maintain eye contact of the youth
at all time and document interval 15-minute checks when they are
unable to and the floater staff will assist with supervision during
dinner and breaks. On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held
with Director. She advised that the agency was able to locate the
video footage, but 30 minutes of the footage was missing. She
reported cameras are motion activated and she is not sure why a
portion of the footage is missing. Director reported speaking with
2

the IT workers and they reported there was no evidence that the
video had been tampered with.
On 7/18/23 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at Ozone
House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1 reported
her role as a youth specialist and stated that she had been
working for the agency for seventh months and is currently on
administrative leave. She reported she was the staff on shift on
6/27/23 when the incident occurred between Youth A and Youth
B. She stated she was not aware the incident had occurred until
Director 3 advised her on 6/30/23. Staff 1 reported she was
cooking dinner and Youth A and Youth B engaged in oral sex in
the recreation room. She confirmed the supervision policy of the
agency requires “eyes on them” and acknowledged she was not
able to see the youth while they were in the recreation room. Staff
1 also advised she is allowed to use the desk camera to assist
with supervision but could not view the cameras from the kitchen.
She stated Youth A and Youth B were out of her view for about 15
to 20 minutes. Staff 1 denied she had been advised of any
previous sexualized behaviors of either Youth A or Youth B. She
reported floater staff assists with supervision of the youth when
staff are required to go to the restroom. Staff 1 further reported the
agency policies change all of the time.
On 07/18/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Director 2 at
Ozone House. The DHHS was also present. Director 2 advised
Staff 1 was placed on administrative leave until the completion of
the investigation. Director 2 confirmed that she would provide
video footage.
On 07/18/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Supervisor at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present.
Supervisor reported she has been employed with the agency for
three to four months. She stated they she and the other staff were
not aware of the incident until Youth A was crying, disclosed the
incident to Staff 3 and wrote a note indicating what happened.
Supervisor reported Staff 3 gave Supervisor the note that had
been written by Youth A. Supervisor reported the letter indicated
Youth B “pressured me to suck his no touch area. He tried to get
me to do it again today”. Supervisor reported after reviewing the
letter, she sent an email to the directors and other employees
advising of what had been reported. She reported Staff 3
continued to talk with Youth A in an attempt to make her feel safe
and comfortable. She confirmed she attempted to use the
camera system to supervise the unit while attending a mandatory
meeting on 6/28/23. Supervisor stated she had to interrupt her
3

meeting to go into the recreation room and ask the youth to come
and sit at a table in front of her because it seemed that they were
trying to hide in the corner out of the view of the camera.
Supervisor also described “supervision” of the youth as having
their eyes on the youth but indicated that staff are allowed to use
the cameras for supervision.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person interview occurred with Staff 3 at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She
reported she has been employed with the agency since February
2022. Staff 3 reported working as a floater staff on the date of the
incident. She went upstairs to check on Youth A as it was
reported she was “having a moment”. She reported speaking with
Youth A in her bedroom and Youth A wanted to tell her something
but did not want to say it out loud. Staff 3 encouraged Youth A to
write it down. Youth A gave Staff 3 a written statement that said
she “sucked Youth B’s no touch spot”. Staff 3 reported she
provided the note to Supervisor. Staff 3 reported she took Youth
A and Youth B to the movies as their planned activity for the
evening. Staff 3 reported the outing occurred without incident.
Staff 3 was unable to advise of what policy indicated was required
for supervision of the youth. She stated she had not been trained
on supervision. Staff 3 reported after the incident occurred, all
staff were advised they have to have eyes on youth at all times.
Staff 3 denied she wrote an incident report and stated she was
told by Supervisor she would take care of it.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Director 3 at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Director 3
reported she has worked at the agency for five years and is
currently serving in the capacity of Director of Residential
Services. Director 3 reported she was advised of the incident on
6/29/2023. She reported Supervisor sent out an email on 6/28/23
about the incident, but it was after hours. She recalled Staff 2
had met with Youth A and Youth B on the morning of 6/29/23 and
discussed the rules of the program. Director 3 further reported
Youth A had provided a short-written statement on 6/28/23 and a
longer statement on 6/29/23. Director 3 stated she reviewed the
camera but did not see anything. Director 3 reported being pulled
into a meeting with Youth A and her therapist to discuss what had
occurred. Director 3 reported she later sent out correspondence
to all staff reminding staff that youth must remain in their line of
sight.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 2 at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She
reported she has been employed with the agency for 6 years and
4

works as a prevention specialist. Staff 2 indicated she believed
she was being interviewed regarding the note Youth A had passed
to Supervisor on 6/28/23. Staff 2 reported she did not recall what
the note was about. She further stated she knew a sexual
“request” had been made by Youth B but stated that it did not
occur. Staff 2 recalled having a conversation with Director 3 the
morning of 6/29/23 but did not recall what they were discussing.
She further stated she came in to work at 10am and met with both
Youth A and Youth B individually. She reported not recalling what
Youth A stated, however she recalled meeting with Therapist
immediately after talking to Youth A. Staff 2 reported she has
never been told what the supervision policy of Ozone House
entails, but she uses sight and sound.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Therapist at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Therapist
reported she was advised by Youth A and other staff about the
incident that occurred between Youth A and Youth B. She held a
therapy session with Youth A on the morning of 6/29/2023. She
reported Youth A told her about a 60-year-old gentleman at her
house that tried to get her to do a sexual act and her mother failed
to protect her and about the incident between her and Youth B
that occurred on 6/27/23.
On 08/08/2023 attempted telephone calls, along with the DHHS
specialist, were made to Supervisor 2 and Therapist 2 without
success.
On both 08/08/2023 and 08/10/2023 a telephone call was made to
Youth B at the home of his caregiver as he had been discharged
from Ozone House. There was no answer, and a message was
left requesting a return call with no response to date.
On both 08/08/2023 and 08/10/2023 a telephone call was made to
Youth A at the contact number of her parent as she had been
discharged from Ozone House. There was no answer, and a
message was left requesting a return call with no response to
date. It should be noted that the mother of Youth A advised the
DHHS specialist that she did not want her daughter to discuss this
issue anymore and that her daughter reported it as a consensual
encounter.
On 08/11/2023 a virtual DHHS case conference was held. DHHS
will be denying their case and there are no findings.
Tour Observation
5

Supervisor escorted DHHS specialist and I on a tour of the facility.
The recreation room is on the direct opposite side of the kitchen
and there is no way to have eyes on the youth while they are in
the recreation room unless you are in the recreation room. The
cameras in the recreation room are not able to capture all areas of
the room. Supervisor was able to point out several camera blind
spots in the recreation room.
Documents Reviewed
Ozone House Supervisor Policy – Policy indicates Youth
Specialist are responsible for knowing the whereabouts of youth
and should monitor and supervise youth activities. The primary
function of residential staff is to ensure the safety of youth,
including enforcing rules and managing behaviors.
Human Resources file of Staff 1 – Formal write up for lack of
supervision noted in file. The write up was a result of the
6/27/2023 incident. Documentation of training on supervision was
included in file, however it was not signed by the employee.
Human Resources file of Supervisor – Verbal warning for lack
of supervision was noted in file. The write up was a result of the
6/28/2023 incident. Documentation of training on supervision was
included in file, however it was not signed by the employee.
Human Resources file of Supervisor 2 - No disciplinary action
noted. Documentation of training on supervision was included in
file, however it was not signed by the employee.
Incident Report from 6/28/2023 – Indicated while staff was in the
kitchen making dinner, Youth A and Youth B were doing sexual
inappropriate things. IR was written by Supervisor.
Incident Report from 7/17/2023 – IR is a total of two pages. In
summary, it documents Youth A and Youth B engaged in sexual
activity and Supervisor was advised by Staff 2. Supervisor sent
email to administrative team advising of the incident. A safety
plan was put into place and no notification to law enforcement or
centralized intake was noted.
Written Statement from Youth A – First statement indicated that
Youth B “pressured me to suck his no touch area. He tried to get
me to do it again today”. Second statement indicated “Youth B
asked me to take a hit of his breeze. He found the corner was
hidden from the camera. He asked for me to get closer. He asked
over and over until eventually I did. He made a joke about his
penis being bigger. I joked back saying mines bigger. He reached
into his pants and pulls his penis out. He asked me in like 5
different ways before I eventually gave a shrug. This was followed
by him placing his hand on my back of my head and pushing me
down on his lap. I gave in and allowed him to take control. He
6

continued to push my head up and down until he came in my
mouth."
Written Statement from Youth B – Statement indicated that he
asked Youth A to "give me head, she said yes. We waited till the
person started to cook because no one was watching the cams."
Ozone House Incident Reporting Policy – Indicated incident
reports are required for any unusual and notable events or
disturbances. Further indicated that if law enforcement
involvement is required the licensing authority will be advised via
IR within 24 hours of incident.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
information to confirm non-compliance by the agency with
licensing rule R 400.4109 (c) relative to supervision. Information
obtained during the investigation confirmed that the staff failed to
provide supervision as indicated in their policy and failed to
provide line of sight supervision.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule R 400.4111 Job description
Section An institution shall provide a job description for each staff position
Description that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of authority.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff failed to meet the requirements as outline in the position job
description.
Investigation On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Director. The
DHHS specialist was also present. The Director advised that her
review of HR files revealed that two of the staff that are currently
employed are not meeting the qualifications as required in the job
description. Therapist does not have a master’s degree as
required but has a school counselors' certificate. Therapist 2 is
required to be a licensed master level clinician however her limited
license expired in April 2023.
Documents Reviewed
Human Resources file of Therapist – Job Description noted that
therapist is required to have a master’s degree in social work.
There was no documentation of a MSW degree in the HR file of
Therapist.
Human Resources file of Therapist 2 – Job Description noted
that therapist is required to maintain social work licensure.
Review of Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs website
indicates that the limited license of therapist 2 expired on
04/30/2019.
7

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
information to confirm non-compliance by the agency with
licensing rule R 400.4111. Information obtained during the
investigation confirmed that two therapists did not meet the criteria
as required in the job description.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required
Description The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to assure
compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL
722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency failed to make a report of suspected abuse and/or
neglect as required by policy.
Investigation On 7/18/2023 a meeting was held with Director at the facility. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Director indicated that the
agency did not call the incident in to Centralized Intake or Law
enforcement immediately because they didn’t really know what to
do about it.
On 07/18/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Supervisor at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present.
Supervisor confirmed the incident was not immediately called in to
centralized intake as she and other staff were not sure of what to
do.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Director 3 at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Director 3
confirmed she did not contact law enforcement or centralized
intake. It was confirmed with Director 3 she was aware of the
content of the first written statement provided by Youth A. She
confirmed that it indicated “he had me suck his no touch area”, but
she stated she did not think the act occurred. She further reported
on 6/29/23 Staff 2 told her that the sexual act had not occurred.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 2 at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
denied that she contacted centralized intake or law enforcement.
She stated that the mother of Youth A did not want to press
charges.
On 08/01/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Therapist at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Therapist
denied she contacted centralized intake or law enforcement.
8

Documents Reviewed
Incident Report from 7/17/2023 – IR is a total of two pages. In
summary, it documents Youth A and Youth B engaged in sexual
activity and Supervisor was advised by Staff 2. Supervisor sent
email to administrative team advising of the incident. A safety
plan was put into place and no notification to law enforcement or
centralized intake was noted.
Ozone House CPL Reporting Procedures – Indicated that
agency staff shall comply with No. 238 of Public Acts of 1975. A
worker who has reasonable cause to suspect abuse or neglect is
required to make a verbal report to MDHHS and submit a 3200
report within 72 hours.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to confirm non-compliance by the agency with licensing
rule R 400.4131. Interviews confirmed that staff failed to report
suspected abuse and neglect as required per policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff failed to perform variable interval eye on checks when youth
were not in direct supervision of staff and/or sleep.
Investigation On 7/18/2023 a meeting was held with Director of Ozone House
at the facility. The DHHS specialist was also present. Director
reported that supervision at night involves staff performing checks
of the youth every 15 minutes. Director also advised Youth A
reported she and Youth B had participated in consensual oral sex.
She reported the youth were in the recreation room when the
incident occurred. Director confirmed staff were utilizing the
cameras as a form of supervision because they were cooking
dinner.
On 7/18/23 an in-person interview was held with Supervisor at
Ozone House. The DHHS specialist was also present. When
asked about bedroom checks for youth in the program, the
Supervisor replied checks are scheduled for every 15 minutes.
On 7/18/23 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at Ozone
House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1 reported
9

she was cooking dinner and Youth A and Youth B engaged in oral
sex in the recreation room. She confirmed the supervision policy
of the agency requires “eyes on them” and acknowledged she was
not able to see the youth while they were in the recreation room.
Staff 1 also advised she is allowed to use the desk camera to
assist with supervision but could not view the cameras from the
kitchen.
Documents reviewed
Ozone House Daily Bed Log Sheets – The daily bed logs were
reviewed during the investigation. The logbook was found to
document checks on the youth exactly 15 minutes apart. There
was not documentation to support interval checks on the youth.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to confirm non-compliance by the agency with licensing
rule R 400.4127. Interviews and review of documents confirmed
that staff failed to ensure "eyes on" checks of residents in 15-
minute varying intervals when they were not directly in the view of
the staff and when they were sleep. Staff admitted that while
youth were in the recreation room that eyes on checks could not
occur and that interval checks were not completed.
Consultation
Licensing rules require “eye on checks”, so cameras can be
utilized to supplement supervision but does not replace the need
for staff to physical see youth without the use of cameras.
Conclusion Violation Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
